posts.cooked:
We noticed that changing to break mode on the falcon 500s yields much better control in some of our pid loops so that the drivetrain does not coast past the setpoint. We are trying to change the modes on the fly in our code here before and after the “turntotarget” command: image 722×146 21 KB

image 722×146 21 KB

image 722×146 21 KB

Though the “SwitchDriveMode” command does not terminate and loops indefinitely. Trying to figure out why this is. This is the code of the command: image 1357×889 126 KB image 1311×784 81 KB

image 1357×889 126 KB

image 1357×889 126 KB

image 1311×784 81 KB

image 1311×784 81 KB

posts.name: Sanjith U
posts.cooked: Your isFinished is returning false, meaning the command scheduler thinks the command is still running and won’t move on to the next command. For something like this you’d either want it to always return true (so it runs execute once) or add a small timeout for setting the mode through CAN, though I don’t think that would be necessary.

posts.name: Colin Wong
posts.cooked: It might be worth to just extend InstantCommand and just call the super constructor with your initialize code.

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked: I would love to learn more on why you think using coast at all for your drivetrain. We’ve never done this before, so I wanna know, @iwumbo , what we are missing?

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked: We were changing modes before climbing for the everybot climber.  Otherwise it doesn’t roll back necessarily (have to drive back).
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked: We were doing it as well in disable mode. Because otherwise it’s like impossible to move the robot.

reply_to_user.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.cooked: Thank you so much! This makes a lot of sense now that I think about it. I’ll try it in our next meeting.

I literally just learned about brake and coast today so its very possible I am misinformed. But I was told that brake mode uses significantly more electricity and would risk the motor burning out a lot more in a match. Considering our robot this year is using cims, using brake mode on srxs would very likely burn out the motors over the course of competition. Which is why we would only use brake mode when we need the precision the most.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked: Using brake mode does not use any electricity from the battery, and will not burn out your motors.
Thank you I’ll look into it
Did you mean that using brake mode over coast doesn’t use any extra electricity? Or that brake mode doesn’t use any electricity at all?

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked:
If you want you can run your own experiment to test current usage in both modes. Your driver’s station does a lot of helpful logging so you can convince yourself which is the best approach.

Keeping your drivetrain in coast mode could be risky cuz when you disable your robot it maintains  it’s inertia, further coasting to whatever danger is in it’s path.
Most definitely I’ll check next meeting. Thank you!

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked: Brake mode connects the motor leads together, basically feeding the generated electricity from the movement of the motor back into itself to resist motion. It does not use any electricity from the battery.
